Award.AwardTitle: RUI/Collaborative Research: Evaluating the Influence of Crustal Deformation on Episodic Magmatism: Southern Coast Mountains Batholith, British Columbia
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will evaluate processes responsible for the non-steady-state growth of continental crust in Cordilleran-type magmatic arcs. These batholiths develop as a result of subduction of oceanic lithosphere at convergent margins, but the processes that control the tempo of magma production are unclear; even in arcs where subduction is continuous, magmatism is strongly episodic (e.g. Sierra Nevada batholith, Peninsular Ranges batholith, Central Andes). Short periods (10-15 million years) of intense magmatism or 'flare-ups' may generate as much as 90% of total batholithic volumes, with little magmatism occurring during intervening lulls. Geochemical and isotopic signatures indicate that magmas produced during flare-ups incorporate more upper plate material than magmas formed during lulls. This pattern raises the question of whether continental growth by magmatic addition is controlled primarily by the behavior of the subducting oceanic plate or by the tectonics of the continental lithosphere at the plate margin. We are investigating this question through an integrated geologic, geochronological and geochemical study of the southern Coast Mountains Batholith in British Columbia. This project directly addresses a basic question in earth science: how do continents grow? In addition to the research goals of this project, this endeavor is enhancing the scientific education and training of students at four academic institutions recognized for the diversity of their student populations. Engagement of students in fieldwork, laboratory analysis, data interpretation and presentation of results are providing them with insights into all aspects of the science process and career options, and increase retention in STEM fields. Samples and datasets generated as a result of this project are being used to design problem sets and interpretive exercises for classes taught by the investigators. Data generated during this the course of this project is being added to NSF-funded databases, such as NAVDAT, for access by the larger community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT: SUMMARY OF FINIDINGS

The main goal of this project was to test ideas on how continental crust forms and evolves at convergent margins, where subduction ultimately converts oceanic crust to continental crust. This conversion occurs through complex processes involving the melting of rocks (magmatism) and emplacement of large magma bodies (plutons) in the crust.  Prior work shows that magmatism is commonly highly episodic, despite fairly steady subduction rates.  This project sought to illuminate the processes that control the pacing of magmatism by examining a little known part the Coast Mountains batholith of British Columbia, one of the world’s largest amalgamation of plutons (a batholith).

We established that magmatism in the Coast Mountains batholith is highly episodic, as found in other batholiths.  Mapping, geochronology, and GIS-based area calculations, show that peaks magmatism peaks at 161–148, 114–102, 85–70, and 61–48 Ma with intervening quiet periods.  Comparison to prior studies (especially  Gehrels et al. 2009) demonstrates that while the batholith is characterized by episodic magmatism, the timing of peak periods does not match along the 1000 km batholith length.  Variations occur over about 150-200 km of batholith, a new and intriguing observation. These local variations in magmatic tempo suggest that local processes, rather than plate-related factors, control the episodic pattern of magmatism commonly found in Cordilleran batholiths. 

One such process may be shortening of the upper crust during periods of contractional deformation (e.g. DeCelles et al., 2009).  Our investigation shows a spatial and temporal linkage of deformation to magmatism: the locus of active deformation occurs where and when magmatism is most active, and the area undergoing deformation migrates northeastward with the magmatic front through time. Deformation, however, does not accompany all periods of high magmatic activity in the study area. Only two of the four documented periods of high magmatism (114-102 Ma and 85 – 70 Ma) occurred during significant deformation, with no widespread deformation recorded during the oldest period (161–148 Ma) nor the youngest period (61–48 Ma). These results suggest that crustal deformation is not required to trigger periods of high magma production. 

Our investigations also revealed that the Coast Mountains batholith is divided along its length by a >1500 km long shear zone that was active between about 85 Ma and 60 Ma. Recognition of this shear zone sheds new light on a long -standing debate over northward translation of crustal fragments along the western margin of North America. The key finding is that the batholith is not a single coherent block, but is split by a major fault that could have accommodated significant northward translation of crustal blocks after they formed in California or northern Mexico.

BROADER IMPACTS: This project contributed to the scientific training of nine Occidental College undergraduate students through field and laboratory opportunities (4 male, 5 female, 2 African American). Two of these students are currently in Ph.D. programs in Geology; one completed a MS in geospatial analysis and works at a federal laboratory. One is a science educator at university-affiliated institution, another is pursuing a degree in environmental law, and another is employed at a geotechnical firm.  Through her work on this project, the P.I. contributed to the training of two Master’s students, one at California State University Northridge, one at the University of Arizona, and one Ph.D. student at the University of Alabama.  In addition, participation in this research enhanced the P.I.’s teaching by improving the collection of samples and photographs used in classes and keeping the P.I. engaged in her field.
